poem:
Assisted Grace

In the cloistered chamber,  
Voices flicker like candle flames,  
Beckon dignity's quiet passage—  
Compassion's gentle tide,  
Softly turning, unresisted.  
Here, in the shadow of robes,  
A whisper—  
Life yields to love,  
To the light those silent hearts  
Seek:  
a peaceful crossing  
into the embrace  
of ending's tender blossom.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. The 26 bishops should “be on the side of those who … want a dignified, compassionate end to their lives”, Lord". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
